Pros: Free breakfast, lunch, high quality snacks and cafes with free coffee and tea.Great benefits with little out of pocket costs.Monthly Uber credits and 17% discount.Monthly stipend for wellness
Cons: Management is slow to invest in technology because they seem to focus on the immediate ROI instead of seeing the long term payoff. Lack of clear expectations by management, which result in a general free for all with everyone trying to work on anything and everything in hopes that it will gain them visibility in the organization. And expect to have hundreds of emails bombard your inbox that you may not even read because at some point you might get asked a question and you have to scour your inbox for some information, but if you can’t find that information someone is going to complain that they weren’t kept up to date on whatever they wanted to know about. It feels like a race to make everything off shore to spend as little as possible. Some teams are probably better than others. Unfortunately favoritism seems to run rampant in some teams probably encouraged by the constant jostling among team members to get their name out there.

I have gotten better bonuses/raises when I stopped caring completely about my work than when I put in the extra effort. Infrastructure teams are completely useless. When I was getting alerted as on-call for an automatically created alert from the infra team, the only thing they could tell me it meant is that something was wrong with my service. Description: Great place to grow and learn

There’s something almost charming about the less formed aspects of the place. The office NEEDS its tech employees. And while comp can seem to be on the low end initially, the numbers are not accurate, or the best way to look at things. Stick around for a few review cycles, and your career will benefit enormously. If nothing else, Uber will teach you a work ethic that is priceless and will make you enormously valuable anywhere else.
Cons: I have way too many black Uber t-shirts. And Beyonce is no longer the holiday party entertainment. C’est la vie. Such is the aftermath with public shareholders.

Cons: Our manager(s) don’t really focus on your career growth. 1-1 meetings typically just revolve around technical thing and how the current project is going. Management never asks any questions about how I want to grow my career, what’s next, etc. I always have to be the one to bring it up, and they never seem to have a good answer. One example is promotions - I mentioned I wanted to go up for a promo, and they basically just said ok, great!. I had to continue the conversation by suggesting things that I can do to strengthen my promo, and they just agreed with me. Not very reassuring

Author Info: Verified User Current Employee w********* Data Analyst - Apr 28, 2021

Pros: Exploring innovative ways to explore career growth that aren’t linear but more or leas experienced based. Autonomy is great and many people dictate their own schedule - less true if you work in HQ. Compensation is great and it’s difficult to find better comp outside but of course there’s equity that drives value. Using Unlimited PTO is encouraged.
Cons: Upward career growth is difficult to achieve. Everyone wants to manage and move to the next level. Uber is a level driven company where everyone works hard to be promoted. WLB can fluctuate - peaks and valleys. We’re still complaining that there’s no 401K match. Company culture is going through hell. Following layoffs we have no idea who we are. We do not show up as one team and people are burnt out leading to high attrition. There’s a struggle between a company that wants to be mature but that also values moving fast and getting shit done which the latter breeds a different type of person that a mature company does not. Management! Oh my goodness, I love Uber but management is terrible. Young or inexperienced, self-seeking, lack of experience in developing / coaching, and some very bad attitudes make up the leaders at Uber. Enter at your own risk and get ready for a wild ride!

Author Info: Verified User Current Employee I***** Account Executive - Jan 25, 2021

Description: Impact work, but doesn’t value its people enough
Pros: Interesting problems and awesome peers. The scale in Rides and Eats is massive, tangible, and impactful. Not a lot of places have the same level of physical and digital world impact that Uber has.
Cons: Day-to-day, your experience can be great and mileage vary depending on your local team. Uber has a lot going for it, but at a high-level, it shoots itself in the foot by not taking care of its own. One would think that after layoffs, the company would spend more time listening and investing in the tenured folks who remain, but attrition and churn continue to run high. Leadership is poor and makes countless myopic decisions that fail in investing in its people. One consequence is the company suffers from a broken perf culture that places more weight on optics, relationships, and snap-judgements from leadership rather than impact.

The Uber Eats/delivery side of the business is growing and expanding into grocery. Engineering talent is top notch. Leadership is transparent. Benefits are great.
Cons: Terrible public reputation; sometimes you feel ashamed/embarrassed that you work for the company. The platform business model is questionable and it doesn't feel good to take fees from drivers and restaurants. We are not profitable. Competition is steep in the food delivery space. Grocery which is meant to be a source of growth has razor thin margins. HR feels unengaged. Salaries are low for tech. A few cliquey tech bros still remain. High team attrition (probably short term though).

Author Info: Verified User Current Employee y***** Senior Software Engineer - Nov 25, 2020

Pros: I’m proud to work at Uber and give people a different way to earn money and support themselves. I have great WLB, like my team, perks are great and improving every day (free meals, new campus in SF, mega backdoor Roth, shuttles, $200-300/month in Uber credit, wellness, phone, etc benefits). Not as good as FB/G but with better WLB/more impact.
Cons: Hmmm I think some of the pains of a startup turned huge corporation. For example, there are directors with <10 years of experience who have been at Uber since the beginning and directors with ~20 years of experience at the same level, which makes the ones with actual experience unhappy and focused on politics rather than the team.Dara also runs this company like a banker and not a founder, which is maybe what we needed but hard to see cool businesses get sold off (JUMP, ATG, global Eats and Rides businesses). I don’t think we are as innovative as we were under Travis, but the culture is much better and we were actually able to IPO and Wall Street likes us, so I’ll take it

Author Info: Verified User Current Employee @**** Software Engineer II - Aug 19, 2020

Pros: - Some incredibly smart engineers! - Cool internal infra: they give you the tools to hack shit up quick- Comp can seem high on paper (company trajectory is meh and future uncertain)- Managers will make you feel like they can give you growth, which feels exciting. Don't fall for this.
Cons: - Toxic. Toxic. Toxic. I dont even know where to start. e.g. --> Aggresive culture: My TL threw his keys at me in a meeting when I couldnt meet a deadline after pushing diffs at 4am and working weekends for monfhs on end to meet a deadline my pushbacks were never taken seriously for. He would stare and grunt at me in meetings if I spoke too much and stole any attention.--> Toe-stepping still encouraged. People will tell you you're leading a project only to secretly create their own project plans and get your project cancelled.--> Ugly politics. People will lie to manuever their way into the right political alliances. Both your teammates and your manager.- The company doesnt care about you. You will realize this on your first day. It's in the air. I made 4 friends during onboarding - 2 of them voluntarily left within 2 months and 1 of them got laid off. - Frontline management is a joke.The company gives them almost no power or no knowledge of whats really happening. Attrition is ridiculous (my manager, skip and his skip all left in my first 7 months). Technical orgs often get managers from product orgs who just simply lack the technical vision to get teams to work together. When manager changes, you basically start proving yourself all over again in your current level. Note: I learnt a lot in my time at the company and met some very great engineers I will always stay in touch with. However, some of my experiences were almost unbelievably dramatic and I want to make sure I highlight this to people before they consider joining.

Pros: You get to work on some of the coolest technology with some of the smartest people on the planet. If you know how to operate in turbulence (shifting projects, unknown requirements, or lack of leadership) and know how to build connections in the organization, then you'll have a good experience. Management is generally flat, so lots of exposure to leadership. Compensation is also great.
Cons: Turbulence, as mentioned before, can be overwhelming at times; there are much smoother operating companies and have their processes in place. Some groups are severely under resourced and overworked leading to burnout. Working at a company as publically vilified as Uber doesn't come without drawbacks, be prepared to have thick skin and go with the flow.

Author Info: Verified User Current Employee s***** Software Engineer - Jun 17, 2020

Description: Used to be a great company, but not any more
Pros: Smart people, solving interesting problems, your work directly impact people's daily life.Free food is OK.
Cons: CEO is not the funder, he does not have the bond to the company & employees as other leaders. Look at the CEO of Airbnb. Although he always deny, I still think he is working to please the wall street and stake holders. I don't really agree with his vision by permanently cut so many jobs during pandemic. Management team has done this back and forth without learning from mistakes. Last year, layoff, then hire crazily with extra amount of refer bonus, there are still tons of positions can not be filled in several months. Now cut so many jobs again, how is the company going to compete after economy recover? So many talented engineers with years of experiences are let go, it's very hard to hire this kind of talent people back. True you can use higher package to attract people who care about TC after recovery, however the lost of knowledge and the damage to the reputation as a tech company can never roll back. As an engineer, I would never want to work for Uber again.
